articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: China's manufacturing activity fell for a fourth straight month in July, albeit at a slower pace, an official factory survey showed on Monday, reinforcing the need for further policy support to boost domestic demand.
articles.title: China's factory activity extends declines, firming case for stimulus

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: China's biggest cities including Beijing and Shenzhen said over the weekend they would implement measures to better meet the needs of homebuyers, without giving details, aiming to prop up a property sector that is seeing few signs of recovery.
articles.title: China's biggest cities vow to introduce steps to boost property sector

articles.author: Leika Kihara
articles.description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has tweaked its bond yield control policy and will allow interest rates to rise more freely, action that market participants have interpreted as the start of a slow shift away from decades of massive monetary stimulus.
articles.title: Explainer: After surprise tweak, what now for BOJ's yield curve control?

articles.author: Ahmad Ghaddar, Arathy Somasekhar, Trixie Yap
articles.description: Oil inventories are beginning to fall in some regions as demand outpaces supply constrained by deep production cuts from OPEC leader Saudi Arabia, providing support for prices which are expected to rise in coming months.
articles.title: Oil inventory drops set stage for higher prices

articles.author: Hugo Dixon
articles.description: The BRICS are an acronym searching for a geopolitical role. When Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa get together for their annual summit in Johannesburg next month, a top issue for discussion will be whether to expand the club. Emerging economies might be better off if it disbands.
articles.title: The BRICS are better off disbanding than expanding

articles.author: Nicholas Brown
articles.description: Warner Bros' (WBD.O) "Barbie" showed no signs of slowing down in its second weekend at the box office, and was set to haul in $93 million in ticket sales Friday through Sunday, according to estimates from media analytics firm Comscore.
articles.title: 'Barbenheimer' box office sales keep rolling in second weekend

articles.author: Leika Kihara
articles.description: Some Bank of Japan (BOJ) policymakers baulked at former chief Haruhiko Kuroda's idea of deploying a "bazooka" massive stimulus a decade ago, unconvinced central banks had the power to jolt public perceptions, accounts of the meeting released on Monday showed.
articles.title: Some at Bank of Japan baulked at ex-chief Kuroda's 'bazooka' stimulus, 2013 meeting minutes show

articles.author: Boureima Balima, Felix Onuah
articles.description: West African nations imposed sanctions and threatened force on Sunday if Niger's coup leaders fail to reinstate ousted President Mohammed Bazoum within a week, while supporters of the junta attacked the French embassy in Niamey.
articles.title: West Africa threatens force on Niger coup leaders, French embassy attacked

articles.author: Tommy Wilkes
articles.description: Banks working to develop global standards on accounting for carbon emissions in bond or stock sale underwriting have voted to exclude most of these emissions from their own carbon footprint, three people familiar with the matter said.
articles.title: Exclusive: Banks vote to limit accounting of emissions in bond and stock sales

articles.author: Sinead Cruise, Lucy Raitano, Lewis Jackson
articles.description: Commercial real estate investors and lenders are slowly confronting an ugly question - if people never again shop in malls or work in offices the way they did before the pandemic, how safe are the fortunes they piled into bricks and mortar?
articles.title: Analysis: Commercial real estate investors risk painful losses in post-COVID world
